choices.D: As a column in a table when you want to store no more than 10 elements in each rowâ€™s collection.
choices.C: When you want to delete elements from the middle of the collection.
choices.A: When the amount of data to be held in the collection is widely variable.
choices.B: As a column in a table when you want to retrieve the collection data for certain rows by ranges of values.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D sounds right - according to https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/appdev.112/e25519/composites.htm#LNPLS99929 where it states "A varray is appropriate when: You know the maximum number of elements."
In my opinion is D

D is the option because varrays are a good choice when the number of elements is known in advance
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B10501_01/appdev.920/a96624/05_colls.htm
D is the correct answer
Why not D? Varrays could be stored in table column and have strict limit for quantity of elements inside.

questions.question_text: Select a valid reason for using VARRAYS.

choices.C: Repetitive SQL queries and PL/SQL function results are cached and automatically used from the cache across all SYS user sessions.
choices.A: The client-side result cache and the server-side result cache are enabled.
choices.B: All distinct query results are cached for the duration of a SYS user session.
choices.D: The result cache exists but which SQL queries are cached depends on the value of the RESULT_CACHE_MODE parameter.
choices.E: Repetitive SQL queries executed on permanent non-dictionary objects may have faster response times.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct according to https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/TGDBA/tune_result_cache.htm#TGDBA640
I think is DE, A could not be because you cant control client side cache.

C is not the answer because the automatic use of DBMS_RESULT_CACHE depends of the RESULT_CACHE_MODE, I think A and D too
https://oracle-base.com/articles/11g/cross-session-plsql-function-result-cache-11gr1

The dbms_result_cache package is used to yield the DBA management options of memory used by both SQL Result Cache and PL/SQL function Result Cache. Here are procedures and functions of the dbms_result_cache package
A,D for me

Selected Answer: B
B is correct, since there are no segment attributes and the schema is null
SEGMENT_ATTRIBUTES: If TRUE, emit segment attributes (physical attributes, storage attributes, tablespace, logging). So, there must be tablespace.

questions.question_text:
Examine this code:
//IMG//

The anonymous block fails with:
ERROR at line 1:

ORA-01403: no data found -

ORA-06512: at line 5 -
Which two are valid options to prevent this error from occurring?

choices.A: Line 5 should be replaced with: DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (pdatabuf (1), TRUE, DBMS_LOB.CALL);
choices.B: Line 5 should be replaced with: DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (pdatabuf (1), FALSE, DBMS_LOB.SESSION);
choices.D: pdatabuf (1) := NULL; should be added after line 4.
choices.C: Rewrite the block as: DECLARE TYPE databuf_arr IS TABLE OF CLOB INDEX BY BINATY_INTEGER; pdatabuf databuf_arr; PROCEDURE mytemplob (x OUT CLOB) IS BEGIN DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (x, TRUE, DBMS_LOB, SESSION); END; BEGIN mytemplob (pdatabuf (1)); END; /
It will display the price increase by 1% only for all the products.
choices.E: It will give an error because PDT_REC is not declared.
choices.A: It will give an error because the calculated column in the cursor is not using a column alias in this block.
choices.B: It will go into an endless loop because the loop exist condition is missing.
choices.D: It will display the price increase by 1% only for the first product.

discussion.content: A, not B. No exit condition is needed because it's a FOR IN loop.

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer
A is right

comments.content: You put an alias on the cursor field in your code. That is why your code did not generate an error. And the correct answer is "A" because alias is needed.
